    • Method Detail

      • addShader

        public ID addShader(java.lang.String pathPrefix,
                    java.lang.String vertexShader_asset,
                    java.lang.String fragmentShader_asset)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaderManagers
        Builds a shader program from the supplied vertex and fragment shader code. The main point of this API is 'discovery,' where you scan the asset directory (or, more typically, some particular subdirectory) looking for shader pairs that you didn't know about at compile time. Secondarily, this can be useful if you have a lot of shader pairs, and would prefer to create a folder per pair and use names like "thisShader/vertex.vsh" and "thisShader/fragment.fsh" rather than "thisShader_vertex.vsh" and "thisShader_fragment.fsh". If neither of this points applies to you, you should use res/raw and the GVRShaderManagers.addShader(int, int) overload, as that presents no dangers of file not found exceptions.
        Specified by:
        addShader in interface GVRShaderManagers<MAP,ID>
        Parameters:
        pathPrefix - Optional (may be null) prefix for shader filenames. If present, will be prepended to vertexShader and fragmentShader, thus allowing you to build a tree of shaders in your assets directory, where each node contains vertex and fragment shaders with the same filename. If null, vertexShader and fragmentShader are the path names of files in the assets directory.

        To be clear: the path names can contain '/' characters, whether or not pathPrefix is null. 

         
 pathPrefix = "foo"; fragmentShader = "bar/fragment.fsh"
 // Asset-relative name is "foo/bar/fragment.fsh" 
 
 pathPrefix = null; fragmentShader = "bar/fragment.fsh"
 // Asset-relative name is "bar/fragment.fsh"
        vertexShader_asset - Filename of a vertex shader, relative to the assets directory
        fragmentShader_asset - Filename of a fragment shader, relative to the assets directory
        Returns:
        An opaque type that you can pass to getShaderMap(ID), or to the GVRMaterial and GVRPostEffect constructors and setShader methods ... or null on any exception, which typically would mean that one or both of the files does not exist or is not readable.

      • addShader

        public ID addShader(int vertexShader_resRaw,
                    int fragmentShader_resRaw)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaderManagers
        Builds a shader program from the supplied vertex and fragment shader code. If you are not doing 'discovery' (scanning the asset directory for shader pairs that you don't know about at compile time) this API is preferable to GVRShaderManagers.addShader(String, String, String), as Android tools can guarantee that the res/raw file exists.
        Specified by:
        addShader in interface GVRShaderManagers<MAP,ID>
        Parameters:
        vertexShader_resRaw - R.raw id, for a file containing a vertex shader
        fragmentShader_resRaw - R.raw id, for a file containing a fragment shader
        Returns:
        An opaque type that you can pass to getShaderMap(ID), or to the GVRMaterial and GVRPostEffect constructors and setShader methods.

      • addShader

        public ID addShader(java.io.InputStream vertexShader_stream,
                    java.io.InputStream fragmentShader_stream)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaderManagers
        Builds a shader program from the supplied vertex and fragment shader code. This overload is used inside of GVRShaderManagers.addShader(int, int) and GVRShaderManagers.addShader(String, String). It may not be incredibly useful to application code, but has been exposed because there's no real reason to keep it hidden.
        Specified by:
        addShader in interface GVRShaderManagers<MAP,ID>
        Parameters:
        vertexShader_stream - GLSL source code for a vertex shader. Stream will be closed when method returns.
        fragmentShader_stream - GLSL source code for a fragment shader. Stream will be closed when method returns.
        Returns:
        An opaque type that you can pass to getShaderMap(ID), or to the GVRMaterial and GVRPostEffect constructors and setShader methods.
